lesson.title: Non-Binary Classification Models
lesson.summary: Build and compare forest and boosted models and interpret their results. Score and compare models and interpret the results.

atoms.title: problem
atoms.text:
**Business problem**

Our company's insurance policy has a reward based benefit offer.  This benefit varies depending on what mode of transportation an employee takes to work. Our company ran a survey to understand the mode of transportation of our employees and only 60% responded. 

What our management would like to do is predict the mode of transportation of the other 40% of employees. This would help us better estimate what benefits we can offer.

atoms.title: Quiz
atoms.text:
Try using your knowledge of Decision Trees to complete the following exercise.

Instructions

Build a Decision Tree out with **Employees Transportation Data** dataset. Confirm there is no missing data and outliers and then create samples of your dataset: * Estimation - 70% * Validation - 30% * Keep defaults for the decision tree model.

question.prompt: What is the overall accuracy of the model viewed from the confusion matrix?

atoms.title: Solution
atoms.text:
Steps to building decision tree

**Input** * Field Summary to check for health * Looks like no outliers * Looks like no missing records **Create Samples** * 70% -Estimation * 30% -Validation **Decision Tree** * Keep configuration options as Defaults **If you are using Alteryx 11 please select this option below on your Decision Tree tool to see the report from the video**

atoms.title: overfitting
atoms.text:
#### Overfitting

When a model is overfitted, it means that the model has focused too much on creating a highly accurate model on the Estimation data at the expense of being able to predict new data well. This means that the model is only a good model just for the Estimation dataset and is not a good model for any new dataset.

You can read up more on [overfitting here](https://www.quora.com/What-is-an-intuitive-explanation-of-overfitting).

atoms.title: Forest Models
atoms.text:
**Decision Trees** 

Decision Trees are prone to an error called over fitting, where the model fits the sample data too well, and as a result, does not predict future results as well as it should.  

A technique that helps to eliminate this issues is the Random Forest Model. 

**Random Forest Model**

* A Forest Model creates hundreds of trees, called an ensemble of decision trees
* Each tree is created by different randomly generated chunks of the original data.  
* It looks at the results as a whole to make a prediction.

Each individual tree created still has overfitting issues, but when you look at the results as a whole, the overfitting gets averaged out by all of the other trees.

atoms.title: note
atoms.text:
**Forest model predictions**

Model applied to a particular employee who lives 1.5 miles away from work.

* Driving - 50% + 20% + 30% / 3 = 33%
* Public Transit - 30% + 30% + 20% / 3 = 27%
* Walking/Biking - 20% + 50% + 50% / 3 = 40%

atoms.title: Build a Forest Model
atoms.instructor_notes: Links to further understand Bootstrapping: [Intuitive Explanation](http://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/26088/explaining-to-laypeople-why-bootstrapping-works) Technical Explanation ---- #### Steps Outlined in Video Input Data Create Samples * 70% Estimation * 30% Validation Forest Model * Number of Trees to use * Min. # records allowed in a tree node * Smaller = more splits

atoms.title: Forest Model Results
atoms.text:
#### Important Definitions

**Out of the Bag Error Rate**

Explains how well the model performed with the cross-validation set in the estimation data. This gives a good understanding of how solid the model performs with just the estimation data.  

You can think of it in the same terms as an R-squared.

**Confusion Matrix** 

Shows again how well the model performed on the original, estimation data. 

Compared to the "Out Of The Bag Error Rate", the confusion matrix does a better job at representing where errors occurred in classifying the data.

**The Percentage Error for Different Number of Trees graph **

Helps us see what the correct number of trees is to use, so we can avoid over computing.  

What we are looking for is the number of trees it takes to minimize the error of each of the items, so basically, where does it flatline? 

After we determine the ideal number of trees, we can change subsequent Forest Models and run our data with the smaller number of Decision Trees.

**Predictor Variables**

Which predictor variables matter the most in relation to this model? This is very helpful in determining which variables are most associated with our data on and we can focus on for future analysis.

atoms.title: Build a Forest Model II
atoms.text:
Viewing the Results

**What we are able to see is:** * Record 3: # of Decision Trees made * Record 4: Out of the Bag estimation error rate * Record 6: Confusion Matrix With this we can see how well the model predicts each employee to what they actually use for transportation to work * Record 8: Percent Error for Different Number of Trees * Y = % Error * X = # Trees **We look to see** * Error Rate * When does it flatline It seems that Public Transportation has the highest error rate and therefore in this model seems to be the toughest to predict. * Record 9: Variable Importance Plot "Looking at the results of this estimation, we had an error rate of only 2.8%. Let's try our model out on the validation sample to determine how well it predicts with independent data." To learn more about the Gini impurity index, [check out this link](https://dinsdalelab.sdsu.edu/metag.stats/code/randomforest.html ).

atoms.title: practice interpreting results
atoms.text:
Practice interpreting results

Practice interpreting results by determining the most important variables in the model results shown.

question.prompt: What are the 3 most important variables in the model results shown above?
What are the 3 most important variables in the model results shown above?

atoms.title: Quiz
atoms.text:
Test the model

The Forest Model performed quite well with the 60% of employees that responded to the survey. Use the validation sample to determine how well our Forest Model actually performed on independent data. **Continue from the same workflow you created with Ben [here](https://classroom.udacity.com/courses/ud978/lessons/1c08dc44-adf2-43ab-bef3-3a6f1b770233/concepts/3355c0b1-1528-4e08-afc3-ae84f1f5d1c4)** * Use the Model Comparison Tool on the Validation sample and Forest Model Object * Review the results

question.prompt: What is the overall accuracy of the model?

atoms.text: # Learning Summary The purpose of this learning summary is to provide the high level steps to build and use Forest and Decision Tree models to make a business decision. Along the side are suggested Alteryx tools to use while implementing the model.

atoms.title: boosted model
atoms.text:
Boosted Model

Forest Models might give us a better estimate than decision trees, but they're computationally intensive. What we need is a model that can be both accurate AND fast. What we'll use to achieve this balance is known as the **Boosted Model**. **How the Boosted model avoids overfitting** * Instead of creating a bunch of random trees, the boosted model makes one tree. * Algorithm performs an analysis on the errors of the tree to identify the biggest source of error. * Changes the tree to reduce that error. * Does the analysis again to find the next biggest error. * Makes a change to reduce it. * Does this over and over until it can’t make the tree any better and we have our finished Boosted Model. To learn more of the mathematical foundation of this model just check out [this link](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gradient_boosting).

atoms.title: Boosted model build model
atoms.text:
**What mode of transportation is used by employees who did not respond to the survey?**

In Alteryx we are now going to use a Boosted Model to try to predict this outcome and then determine how well it fares as a model.

**Input Data**
**Create Sample Tool**
* 70% Estimation
* 30% Validation

**Boosted Model**
* Specify target variable type - Multinomial

To learn more about more advanced configurations, check out [this link](http://help.alteryx.com/10.1/index.htm#cshid=Boosted_Model.htm).

atoms.title: Boosted model observe results
atoms.text:
Main points of the output

**What we are able to see:** Record 1: * Loss Function Distribution * Number of trees used Record 2: * Variable Importance Plot This is similar to what we observed in the Forest Model where the Drive Distance is the more important variable to the model followed by Age. The relative importance of the Drive Distance is 60% to the overall model. Record 3: * The deviance is captured with more iterations. What this shows is that the more trees added the smarter the prediction became. The Estimation sample and In-Model sample estimate that are built into this model are very close, meaning this model performs well on an independent sample.

atoms.title: Boosted Model Validation
atoms.text:
Validate by applying the model to the validation set and observing the accuracy.

In Alteryx, we’ll use the Model Comparison tool as we did for the other models. **Steps** Have the model already built out Model Comparison Tool * Record 2: * Overall Accuracy of the Model * Overall Accuracy of different categories * Record 3: * Confusion Matrix By looking at this Model Comparison Report it seems that we have a very solid model. **Overall accuracy**: .8323,

atoms.title: Model Comparison
atoms.instructor_notes:
Comparing our 3 Classification Models

**Model Accuracy** If we look at the model accuracy we see that the Forest Model performed best, followed up by a very close second with the Decision Tree model. And coming in 3rd was the Boosted model. The Forest Model provides the highest accuracy, and there are now 2 reasons to pick the Forest Model: 1. It has the highest overall accuracy 2. The averaged results from the forest model helps deal with the decision tree model's bias to overfit the data

atoms.title: Score the Missing Data
atoms.text:
Now that we have chosen the Forest Model use this to predict the mode of transportation the other 40% of employees take to work.

Using Alteryx, accomplish this task using the score tool like we did in the previous lesson.

Take the model and score the rest of the employees from the **Missing Employees** file below.

question.prompt: How many employees take a bike to work?
How many employees take their car to work?
How many employees take a public transportation to work?

atoms.title: score the missing data steps
atoms.text:
**How to complete this exercise**

1) Have built out Forest Model

2) Bring in Score tool

* Model Object

*  New Input Dataset

3) Browse results

4) Formula tool to code into 1’s and 0’s

* Transpose and filter to only have the 1 value that they chose

Now what we have is the mode of transportation for each of the 40% of employees that didn’t respond to that survey.

**Note**: In general after determining the best model we want to feed it all the data we can before using it to predict other outcomes. In this example we are still only using a sample of the data but in practice you would want to use all of it to build your model.

atoms.title: outro
atoms.text:
**Lesson Overview**

This section was all about trying to classify non-binary data, we attacked this by a very methodical approach that was very similar to classifying binary data.

What we did...

* Examined our data.
* Created samples of our dataset
* Tested our sample on 3 model types 
* Compared our models using the validation dataset
* Chose our model based on how it performed and just old fashioned intuition. 

If you are a Nanodegree student taking this course, you are now ready to do the project.

# Learning Summary The purpose of this learning summary is to provide the high level steps to build and use Boosted models to make a business decision. Along the side are suggested Alteryx tools to use while implementing the model.
